head.title: The Fire This Time: Seeking a Way Out

hedline.hl1: The Fire This Time: Seeking a Way Out

abstract.p: Joel B Smith letter on June 23 article on wildfires afflicting Western states warns climate change is likely to worsen problem; drawing

block.p: The immediate causes for the vast wildfires afflicting the Southwest (''Era of the Big Fire Is Kindled at West's Doors,'' front page, June 23) are extreme drought and fire suppression in combination with rapidly growing populations living in the ''urban-wildland interface.''

The immediate causes for the vast wildfires afflicting the Southwest (''Era of the Big Fire Is Kindled at West's Doors,'' front page, June 23) are extreme drought and fire suppression in combination with rapidly growing populations living in the ''urban-wildland interface.''
Climate change is likely to make Western wildfires worse. Higher temperatures will increase drying and need for water by forests.
If precipitation decreases, the forests become drier and more fires will happen. If precipitation increases, forests will grow more during wet years, increasing the fuel load.
Then, during inevitable dry years (because the West has high variability in year-to-year precipitation), that additional fuel will be prone to fire. Either way, the potential for fires increases.
JOEL B. SMITH Boulder, Colo., June 24, 2002
The writer is an environmental consultant specializing in global warming.
